head.title: The Gift of Life, Even at the End

hedline.hl1: The Gift of Life, Even at the End

abstract.p: Debbie J Peters letter agrees with Dr David A Shaywitz (Sept 19 Op-Ed) that concern for a 'good death' can be taken too far (S)

block.p: I agree with David A. Shaywitz that ''concern for a good death can be taken too far'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 19). The trend toward the ''sooner rather than later'' withholding of routine medical treatments for the demented elderly (like antibiotics) and the substituting of ''comfort care'' is rife for such abuse.

I agree with David A. Shaywitz that ''concern for a good death can be taken too far'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 19). The trend toward the ''sooner rather than later'' withholding of routine medical treatments for the demented elderly (like antibiotics) and the substituting of ''comfort care'' is rife for such abuse.
Widespread discontent with escalating health care costs may only fuel this practice.

Such a putatively humane approach is justified, in part, by the unproven assumption that these individuals have a poor quality of life. In fact, most residents with dementia in reputable nursing homes appear content and respond positively to regular personal attention.
Before we further promulgate this changing ethic, we must mandate an open, informed debate on its life-and-death consequences.
DEBBIE J. PETERS New York, Sept. 21, 2000
